Description: Fertilization occurs, and the zygote forms.
Mother's Body Changes: Nothing yet
Common Symptoms: Not technically pregnant yet.

Description: Fertilization occurs, and the zygote forms.
Mother's Body Changes: Nothing yet
Common Symptoms: Not technically pregnant yet.

Description: The zygote becomes a blastocyst and implants in the uterine wall.
Mother's Body Changes: Hormonal changes begin as the body prepares for pregnancy.
Common Symptoms: Not technically pregnant yet.

Description: The embryo starts to form, and the placenta begins to develop.
Mother's Body Changes: Implantation bleeding may occur; hormone levels rise.
Common Symptoms: Implantation bleeding.

Description: The neural tube closes, and the heart starts to beat.
Mother's Body Changes: Morning sickness and fatigue are common.
Common Symptoms: Morning sickness.

Description: The embryo's major organs and structures begin to form.
Mother's Body Changes: Breast tenderness and frequent urination begin.
Common Symptoms: Breast tenderness and frequent urination.

Description: The embryo's facial features start to develop.
Mother's Body Changes: Increased blood volume; hormonal changes continue.
Common Symptoms: Increased blood volume and hormonal changes.

Description: The embryo's limbs and fingers begin to form.
Mother's Body Changes: The uterus expands; weight gain may start.
Common Symptoms: Uterus expands and weight gain may start.

Description: The embryo's major organs continue to develop.
Baby Size Information: Baby’s measurement is from crown to rump
Mother's Body Changes: Increased appetite; possible food cravings.
Common Symptoms: Increased appetite and possible food cravings.

Description: The embryo becomes a fetus, and the tail disappears.
Baby Size Information: Baby’s measurement is from crown to rump
Mother's Body Changes: The belly starts to show; skin changes may occur.
Common Symptoms: Belly starts to show and skin changes may occur.

Description: The fetus's vital organs are fully formed and functioning.
Baby Size Information: Baby’s measurement is from crown to rump
Mother's Body Changes: Increased energy levels; reduced morning sickness.
Common Symptoms: Increased energy levels and reduced morning sickness.

Description: The fetus's genitals begin to develop.
Baby Size Information: Baby’s measurement is from crown to rump
Mother's Body Changes: The belly continues to grow; mother may feel fetal movements.
Common Symptoms: Belly continues to grow and mother may feel fetal movements.

Description: The fetus's fingers and toes are fully formed.
Baby Size Information: Baby’s measurement is from crown to rump
Mother's Body Changes: Increased blood flow; possible varicose veins.
Common Symptoms: Increased blood flow and possible varicose veins.

Description: The fetus's bones start to harden.
Baby Size Information: Baby’s measurement is from crown to rump
Mother's Body Changes: Mother may experience back pain; leg cramps.
Common Symptoms: Back pain and leg cramps.

Description: The fetus's hair and eyebrows begin to grow.
Baby Size Information: Baby’s measurement is from crown to rump
Mother's Body Changes: Belly becomes more prominent; stretch marks may appear.
Common Symptoms: Belly becomes more prominent and stretch marks may appear.

Description: The fetus can make facial expressions.
Baby Size Information: Baby’s measurement is from crown to rump
Mother's Body Changes: Mother may experience shortness of breath; heartburn.
Common Symptoms: Shortness of breath and heartburn.

Description: The fetus's eyes can move, and it can hear sounds.
Baby Size Information: Baby’s measurement is from crown to rump
Mother's Body Changes: Belly continues to grow; mother may feel Braxton Hicks contractions.
Common Symptoms: Belly continues to grow and mother may feel Braxton Hicks contractions.

Description: The fetus's lungs continue to develop.
Baby Size Information: Baby’s measurement is from crown to rump
Mother's Body Changes: Mother may experience swelling in hands and feet.
Common Symptoms: Swelling in hands and feet.

Description: The fetus's digestive system is fully formed.
Baby Size Information: Baby’s measurement is from crown to rump
Mother's Body Changes: Mother may feel more tired; difficulty sleeping.
Common Symptoms: Mother may feel more tired and have difficulty sleeping.
Important Milestones:
Baby begins making noticeable
movements, can hear sounds,
and gender can be found out.

Mother's Body Changes: Belly continues to grow; mother may experience pelvic pain.

Baby begins making noticeable
movements, can hear sounds,
and gender can be found out.

Mother's Body Changes: Mother may feel more tired; difficulty sleeping.

Description: The fetus's brain is rapidly developing.
Baby Size Information: Baby’s measurement is from crown to heel
Mother's Body Changes: Increased heartburn and indigestion.
Common Symptoms: Increased heartburn and indigestion.

Description: The fetus's eyes can open and close, and it can respond to light.
Baby Size Information: Baby’s measurement is from crown to heel
Mother's Body Changes: More frequent fetal movements.
Common Symptoms: More frequent fetal movements.

Description: The fetus's immune system is developing.
Baby Size Information: Baby’s measurement is from crown to heel
Mother's Body Changes: Increased swelling in hands and feet.

Description: The fetus's lungs are fully developed but not yet mature.
Baby Size Information: Baby’s measurement is from crown to heel
Mother's Body Changes: Mother may feel more tired; difficulty sleeping.
Common Symptoms:
Sure, here's a more summarized version:

At 27 weeks pregnant, both you and your baby are experiencing significant changes:

* Baby's Development: The baby is about 35 cm long and weighs around 820 grams. The brain and lungs are still developing, and the baby is practicing swallowing amniotic fluid.
* Mother's Changes: You may gain about 500 grams per week and feel more tired. The uterus is now above the belly button, and progesterone is causing the pelvis to soften, which can lead to pelvic pain.
* Interaction with Baby: You can start feeling the baby move by placing your hand on your belly.
* Colostrum Production: From the 26th week, you might notice colostrum, the first breast milk, leaking from your nipples. It's rich in nutrients and antibodies for the baby.

Description: The fetus gains weight rapidly.
Baby Size Information: Baby’s measurement is from crown to heel
Mother's Body Changes: Increased back pain; difficulty moving.
Common Symptoms:
Baby's Development:
* Weight & Length: About 1 kg and 36 cm long.
* Senses: Well-developed; can see, hear, feel, and taste.
* Skin: Produces sebum and vernix to prevent drying out.
* Body Proportion: Head-to-body ratio remains the same until birth.
* Weight Differences: Boys weigh 1030-1190 grams, girls 960-1110 grams.

Changes in You:
* Baby's Movements: Feel kicks daily; recognize movement patterns.
* Monitoring Movements: If no movement is felt, rest and try to make contact. If still quiet after an hour, call your midwife/doctor or medical practicioner.
* Pregnancy Line: Dark line from navel due to pigment accumulation, which fades post-pregnancy. Increased pigmentation may also appear on nipples and labia.

Take time to feel your baby's movements and enjoy this special phase! 😊

Description: The fetus's brain continues to develop rapidly.
Baby Size Information: Baby’s measurement is from crown to heel
Mother's Body Changes: More frequent fetal movements.
Common Symptoms:
Baby's Development:
* Size and Weight: Your baby is now 38.5 cm long and weighs 1100 grams.
* Rhythm: Developing a fixed sleep and activity pattern.
* Brain Development: The brain can now control body temperature and breathing.
* Hearing: Your baby can hear your heartbeat, blood flow, digestion, your voice, and music.

Changes in Your Body:
* Pelvic Pain: Common in one in four women due to changes in the pelvis. Chiropractic and osteopathy can help.
* Baby's Movements: You may feel your baby's bottom and feet pressing against your stomach and diaphragm.
* Blood Pressure: Regularly monitored during check-ups to prevent high blood pressure or pregnancy-related conditions.
* Workplace Adjustments: Employers are required to accommodate your needs and protect against pregnancy discrimination.

Tips:
* Nutrition: Ensure you get the right nutrients, especially in the last trimester.
* Rest: Sit down and rest more often as your baby grows and puts pressure on your body.
* Maternity Leave: It's almost time for your maternity leave, so hang in there!
